description: With the advent of the HTML5 Canvas tag, the world of graphical manipulation in the browser has become a reality. This series is an exploration of some the possibility that are available when using the canvas element. The ultimate aim is to use project-based exploration of the capabilities of the HTML5 Canvas element by building games as well as some utilities. Along the way, you may learn some other interesting JavaScript uses. See you there!

name: HTML5 Canvas Projects
subtitle: Learn HTML5 Canvas by doing

episodes.description: With the advent of the HTML5 Canvas tag, the world of graphical manipulation in the browser has become a reality. This series is an exploration of some the possibility that are available when using the canvas element. The ultimate aim is to use project-based exploration of the capabilities of the HTML5 Canvas element by building games as well as some utilities. Along the way, you may learn some other interesting JavaScript uses. See you there!
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.115
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.115 --> 00:00:07.550
Hello and thank you for
choosing DevPro TV.

3
00:00:07.550 --> 00:00:12.005
We're talking about HTML5 canvas
projects with Justin Dennison.

4
00:00:12.005 --> 00:00:14.510
Justin, give us an overview,
what's the course like?

5
00:00:14.510 --> 00:00:18.380
>> So this course is to really submit
some of the skills maybe you've acquired

6
00:00:18.380 --> 00:00:20.350
through HTML5 canvas.

7
00:00:20.350 --> 00:00:23.700
I know what the canvas element is,
I know the 2D rendering context,

8
00:00:23.700 --> 00:00:25.900
but how do these all come into play,
what can I build?

9
00:00:25.900 --> 00:00:29.380
So what I've done during this
course is created a few projects,

10
00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:32.020
a couple of games and
a couple of non-games.

11
00:00:32.020 --> 00:00:36.720
Where we can really apply the skills that
we know, the features about the HTML5

12
00:00:36.720 --> 00:00:40.630
canvas, as well as sprinkled in a few
other things from web development.

13
00:00:40.630 --> 00:00:41.820
What are we gonna build?

14
00:00:41.820 --> 00:00:45.250
Well, we have a couple of simple
games like Atmos Attackers.

15
00:00:45.250 --> 00:00:49.020
We have little creatures coming down
the screen and we're fending them off.

16
00:00:49.020 --> 00:00:49.830
What else?

17
00:00:49.830 --> 00:00:51.160
We have an image editor.

18
00:00:51.160 --> 00:00:54.430
We have the ability to paint and scribe.

19
00:00:54.430 --> 00:00:59.050
And well, a few other ones, but you'll
have to come and see to figure those out.

20
00:00:59.050 --> 00:01:01.050
>> Now who is this show targeted towards?

21
00:01:01.050 --> 00:01:05.510
>> So this show is definitely for someone
who has some previous web development

22
00:01:05.510 --> 00:01:10.430
experience and admittedly,
some HTML5 canvas element experience.

23
00:01:10.430 --> 00:01:12.200
What does that mean?

24
00:01:12.200 --> 00:01:14.590
That means you need to know some
JavaScript, you need to know some HTML,

25
00:01:14.590 --> 00:01:18.750
you need to know probably not
as much CSS as some other people

26
00:01:18.750 --> 00:01:19.920
may require you to know.

27
00:01:19.920 --> 00:01:22.870
But if you don't know those, then a lot of
the things that I'm gonna be doing in this

28
00:01:22.870 --> 00:01:24.990
course, well,
they're gonna become difficult.

29
00:01:24.990 --> 00:01:29.070
They may not have any real kind of
impetus of why I am doing them.

30
00:01:29.070 --> 00:01:34.110
So, I would say this is more of
an intermediate level skill set required,

31
00:01:34.110 --> 00:01:35.730
in order to start leveling up.

32
00:01:35.730 --> 00:01:39.110
Now, with that said, that does not mean
that it cannot be approachable for

33
00:01:39.110 --> 00:01:44.000
someone who, maybe has just started, and
wants to see what the capabilities are for

34
00:01:44.000 --> 00:01:45.750
the HTML5 canvas element.

35
00:01:45.750 --> 00:01:48.553
>> Justin, is there a certification
available for this?

36
00:01:48.553 --> 00:01:52.680
>> So for this course,
there is no certification available.

37
00:01:52.680 --> 00:01:56.710
Mainly because it's gear toward, I know
a little bit, and I wanna know more.

38
00:01:56.710 --> 00:01:58.300
I want to take the next step.

39
00:01:58.300 --> 00:02:00.540
I want to power up, level up, so to speak.

40
00:02:00.540 --> 00:02:04.184
So there is no explicit certification
other than the wonderful warm,

41
00:02:04.184 --> 00:02:07.990
fuzzy feeling that you get by
creating graphics within the browser.

42
00:02:07.990 --> 00:02:11.340
And seeing some of the power that is
divvied out by the browser environment.

43
00:02:11.340 --> 00:02:13.440
>> So what topics are covered in the show?

44
00:02:13.440 --> 00:02:21.112
>> So this show is taking those
HTML5 canvas elements, like figures.

45
00:02:21.112 --> 00:02:25.545
I have the canvas element, I have the 2D
rendering context, and now I wanna

46
00:02:25.545 --> 00:02:29.630
learn how to create data models,
in order to create a user interface,

47
00:02:29.630 --> 00:02:33.800
in order to create interactivity to
create games like Atmo Attackers.

48
00:02:34.990 --> 00:02:38.080
As well as, how do I draw on this?

49
00:02:38.080 --> 00:02:39.540
What kind of data structures do I need?

50
00:02:39.540 --> 00:02:40.610
How do I think about this?

51
00:02:40.610 --> 00:02:41.690
How do I attack?

52
00:02:41.690 --> 00:02:44.593
Now I know that was
very general in nature.

53
00:02:44.593 --> 00:02:50.598
So it is more about application
of the HTML 5 canvas element and

54
00:02:50.598 --> 00:02:53.670
its associated kind of pieces.

55
00:02:53.670 --> 00:02:57.640
About how to attack and
approach solving a problem.

56
00:02:57.640 --> 00:02:58.846
I have an idea for
something I want to build.

57
00:02:58.846 --> 00:03:02.424
How do I take the skill set
that I know a little bit about,

58
00:03:02.424 --> 00:03:05.481
plan it out, and
then make it come to fruition.

59
00:03:05.481 --> 00:03:07.670
>> Well, this sounds like
something you're excited about.

60
00:03:07.670 --> 00:03:08.350
And I know I am.

61
00:03:08.350 --> 00:03:13.980
You're going to make sure to watch every
single episode of HTML5 canvas projects.

62
00:03:13.980 --> 00:03:17.564
Thank you for watching DevPro TV.

63
00:03:17.564 --> 00:03:20.967
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Justin and Zach begin to build their homage to the game PONG, stress the importance of knowing about HTML5 Canvas Planning, using ATOM for text editor, use Chrome as web browser, file-add project folder, animations can be on a single HTML Page, C55, <!DocType html>, using the Mozilla Developer Network, and Console.Log.
episodes.title: Project Planning and Setup

episodes.description: Justin and Zach begin to create the 'Ball' to be used in their home to the game PONG, what we need to think about in creating it, Angular JS is the running logic, using UPDATE-RENDER-DATA, App. JS is the game state, and if we need to make the ball circular and why.
episodes.title: Creating the Ball

episodes.description: Justin and Zach explain a general approach of creating a paddle object to illustrate designing the paddle for the player and for the computer, showing how to utilize this custom object to extend for use as a player paddle as well as a computer paddle.
episodes.title: Creating the Paddle

episodes.description: Justin and Zach continue to build of their homage to PONG, and demonstrate the use of the standard paddle to create  a player controlled paddle.
episodes.title: Creating the Human Player Paddle

episodes.description: Justin and Zach create the computer paddle that the game will use to play against the human player, demonstrating how to create different strategies that can be applied to the computer player. Part 1.
episodes.title: Creating the Computer Player Paddle

episodes.description: Justin and Zach continue to create the computer paddle that the game will use to play against the human player, demonstrating how to create different strategies that can be applied to the computer player. Part 2.
episodes.title: Creating the Computer Player Paddle Part 2

episodes.description: Justin and Zach add some structure to the Game by creating a managing Game Object that will oversee the Game, and setting up further expansion to score inclusion & other "setup" plus "managed" features. Part 1.
episodes.title: Refactoring into a Game Object

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach continue the discussion about adding some structure to the game by creating a managing game object that will oversee the game, using this time to setup for further expansion to score inclusion & other "setup" & "managed" features.
episodes.title: Refactoring into a Game Object Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach conclude the discussion about adding some structure to the game by creating a managing game object that will oversee the game, using this time to setup for further expansion to score inclusion & other "setup" & "managed" features.
episodes.title: Refactoring into a Game Object Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach take us through creating a scoreboard that will take both of the players, and the scoreboard will be used to determine the game winning condition.
episodes.title: Creating the Scoreboard

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin demonstrates how to change the the paddle objects to become aware of the ball object. By doing this, the paddle can determine if the ball has collided with it. Moreover, Justin discusses how this method compares and contrasts with making the ball aware of the paddle.
episodes.title: Detecting Collisions

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin shows the design of the image editor that we are going to create in the browser. He shows how the planning leads to knowing how to implement a solution based on small pieces of a project.
episodes.title: Designing an Image Editor

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin demonstrates implementing the interface design from the previous episode. As a first pass on the layout, this may change as more functionality is necessary.
episodes.title: Setting up the Interface

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin demonstrates obtaining an image from a local source. Moreover, he shows how to hold the image into an in-memory representation to be manipulated and drawn.
episodes.title: Accessing the Image

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin demonstrates building different image manipulation filters that are going to be available in the applicaton such as greyscale, sepia, and blurring.
episodes.title: Building Image Manipulation Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach demonstrate different image manipulation filters that are going to be available in the application such as greyscale-sepia-blurring, and we begin this episode by covering why we need to make copies.
episodes.title: Building Image Manipulation Functions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin demonstrates how to take the one can use the browser functionality to create a downloaded file that is a copy of the transformed image.
episodes.title: Saving the Image

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin plans out the project for AtmoAttackers. He designs the interface as well as the interactions that are necessary for creating the game dynamic. Moreover, he sets up the project structure in preparation for implementing the game.
episodes.title: Planning the Project

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin creates a basic fighter object that will be controlled by the player. He uses a simplified version [rectangle] to get the placement and movements wired up.
episodes.title: Creating a Basic Fighter

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin creates a simple attacker. He demonstrates creating the data representation, how the attacker will move, as well as rendering the attacker to the game screen.
episodes.title: Creating a Basic Attacker

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin creates the data representation of a pellet as well as how it will be rendered on the screen. Moreover, Justin creates the user input instructions for firing the pellets from the fighter as well as demonstrates how to manage the limitations of having multiple pellets.
episodes.title: Creating the Pellets

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin alters the interactions of the pellets in order to remove the pellets from play if they contact an attacker as well as limit the amount of pellets on screen to eliminate spamming the fire button.
episodes.title: Creating the Pellets Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin takes some time to organize and cleanup as well as refactor the code to separate the concerns of the fighter, attacker, and pellet structures. Moreover, Justin creates a main game object that will be used to manage the animation and interactions.
episodes.title: Cleaning Up and Refactoring

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin creates a swarm of attackers that behave in unison. Moreover, he shows that the swarm now defines the collection of attackers, but that the attackers can still have behaviors and properties themselves. The swarm object allows easier management of the collection of attackers.
episodes.title: Creating a Swarm

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin refactors the original implementation of the swarm of attackers in order to address the changing boundary issues as well as make the main game code more readable.
episodes.title: Creating a Swarm Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Zack and Justin return to the game to add image based sprites to the fighter and attacker.
episodes.title: Adding Sprites

episodes.description: In this episode, Zack and Justin return to the game to add image based sprites to the attacker.
episodes.title: Adding Sprites Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Zack and Justin demonstrate adding sound to the game in order to add a little extra flair to the playing experience.
episodes.title: Adding Sounds

episodes.description: In this episode, Zack and Justin continue adding sounds to the game including fixing the lag between rapid fire shots and the pellet sound, the game over sound as well as the explosion sounds upon enemy destruction.
episodes.title: Adding Sounds Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Zack and Justin explore how the game over state of the game is decided. More specifically, Justin demonstrates how to manage the two states of the game, the attackers reach the fighter or the fighter destroys all of the attackers.
episodes.title: Ending the Game

episodes.description: In this episode, Zack and Justin plan out a graphical editing application in the browser that will allow for basic drawing in the browser.
episodes.title: Planning The Devpaint Project

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin get started implementing the first drawing capability of DevPaint.
episodes.title: Creating A Pencil Drawing

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin take a look at how to fix the tracking of the pointer in order to make the rendering of the line more accurate to the mouse cursor. Justin also refactors the application code to provide a little more readability.
episodes.title: Creating a Pencil Drawing Pt2

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin fix the single continuous path so that users can draw multiple yet separate lines. In order to accomplish this, Justin introduces a new object into the application and refactors, yet again, the application code.
episodes.title: Creating a Pencil Drawing Pt3

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin demonstrate how to use new features of HTML5 to interface with DevPaint to allow selecting different colors.
episodes.title: Adding Color Selections

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin describe and implement the ability to change the pen tool size when drawing. Justin emphasizes how that information propagates to other objects within the application.
episodes.title: Adding Size Choices

episodes.description: In this episode, Zack and Justin demonstrate how to save the masterpieces that you have drawn with the tool.
episodes.title: Saving the Image
